6-K 1 nufs1q23_6k.htm 6-K SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION Washington, D.C. 20549 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; FORM 6-K Report of Foreign Private Issuer Pursuant to Rule 13a-16 or 15d-16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 &nbsp; For the month of May, 2023 Commission File Number 001-41129 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. (Exact name of registrant as specified in its charter) &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. (Translation of Registrant's name into English) &nbsp; Campbells Corporate Services Limited, Floor 4, Willow House, Cricket Square, KY1-9010 Grand Cayman, Cayman Islands +1 345 949 2648 (Address of principal executive office) &nbsp; Indicate by check mark whether the registrant files or will file annual reports under cover Form 20-F or Form 40-F. &nbsp; Form 20-F ( X ) Form 40-F &#9; &nbsp; Indicate by check mark whether the registrant by furnishing the information contained in this Form is also thereby furnishing the information to the Commission pursuant to Rule 12g3-2(b) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934. Yes &#9; No ( X ) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Contents &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements of Profit or Loss &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements of Comprehensive Income or Loss &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements Statements of Financial Position &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements of Changes in Equity &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Independent Auditors&rsquo; report on review of Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements &nbsp; To Board of Directors and Shareholders of Nu Holdings Ltd. Cayman Islands &nbsp; Introduction We have reviewed the accompanying unaudited interim condensed consolidated statement of financial position of Nu Holdings Ltd. (&ldquo;Company&rdquo;) as at March 31, 2023, the unaudited interim condensed consolidated statements of profit or loss, comprehensive income or loss, changes in equity and cash flows for the three-month period then ended, and notes to the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements. &nbsp; Management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements in accordance with IAS 34, &lsquo;Interim Financial Reporting&rsquo; issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB). Our responsibility is to express a conclusion on these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements based on our review. &nbsp; Scope of review We conducted our review in accordance with Brazilian and International Standards on Review (NBC TR 2410 - Revis&atilde;o de Informa&ccedil;&otilde;es Intermedi&aacute;rias Executada pelo Auditor da Entidade and ISRE 2410 - Review of Interim Financial Information Performed by the Independent Auditor of the Entity , respectively). A review of interim financial information consists of making inquiries, primarily of persons responsible for financial and accounting matters, and applying analytical and other review procedures. A review is substantially less in scope than an audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on Auditing and consequently does not enable us to obtain assurance that we would become aware of all significant matters that might be identified in an audit. Accordingly, we do not express an audit opinion. &nbsp; &nbsp; Conclusion Based on our review, nothing has come to our attention that causes us to believe that the accompanying unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements as of March 31, 2023, are not prepared, in all material respects, in accordance with IAS 34, &lsquo;Interim Financial Reporting&rsquo;. &nbsp; &nbsp; S&atilde;o Paulo, May 15, 2023. &nbsp; &nbsp; /s/ KPMG Auditores Independentes Ltda. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Statements of Profit or Loss For the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 and 2022 (In thousands of U.S. Dollars, except earnings (loss) per share) &nbsp; 4,310,496 &nbsp; 2,968,622 Increase (decrease) in cash and cash equivalents &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 67,651 &nbsp; 265,729 &nbsp; The accompanying notes are an integral part of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements. &nbsp; 11 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Notes to the Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (In thousands of U.S. Dollars, unless otherwise stated) &nbsp; 1. OPERATIONS &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. (&quot;Company&quot; or &quot;Nu Holdings&quot;) was incorporated as an exempted Company under the Companies Law of the Cayman Islands on February 26, 2016. The address of the Company's registered office is Willow House, 4 th floor, Cricket Square, Grand Cayman - Cayman Islands. Nu Holdings has no operating activities with clients. &nbsp; The Company&#8217;s shares are publicly traded on the New York Stock Exchange (&quot;NYSE&quot;) under the symbol &#8220;NU&#8221; and its Brazilian Depositary Receipts (&quot;BDRs&quot;) are traded on B3 - Brasil, Bolsa, Balc&atilde;o (&quot;B3&quot;), the Brazilian stock exchange, under the symbol &quot;NUBR33&quot;. The Company holds investments in several operating entities and, as of March 31, 2023, its significant operating subsidiaries were: &#9679; Nu Pagamentos S.A. - Institui&ccedil;&atilde;o de Pagamento (&#8220;Nu Pagamentos&#8221;) is an indirect subsidiary domiciled in Brazil. Nu Pagamentos is engaged in the issuance and administration of credit cards and payment transfers through a prepaid account, and participation in other companies as partner or shareholder. Nu Pagamentos has as its primary products: (i) a Mastercard international credit card (issued in Brazil where it allows payments for purchases to be made in monthly installments), fully managed through a smartphone app, and (ii) NuConta, a 100% digital smartphone app, maintenance-free prepaid account, which also includes features of a traditional bank account, such as electronic and peer-to-peer transfers, bill payments, withdrawals through the 24 Hours ATM network, instant payments, prepaid credit for mobile top ups and prepaid cards similar in functionality to debit cards. &#9679; Nu Financeira S.A. &#8211; SCFI (&#8220;Nu Financeira&#8221;) is an indirect subsidiary also domiciled in Brazil, with personal loans and retail deposits as its main products. Nu Financeira offers customers in Brazil the possibility to obtain loans that can be customized in relation to amounts, terms and conditions, number of installments, and transparent disclosure of any charges involved in the transaction, fully managed through the above-mentioned smartphone app. Loan issuance, repayment, and prepayments are available 24/7 through NuConta's account, directly in the app. Nu Financeira also grants credit to Nu Pagamentos credit card holders, due to overdue invoices, bill installments and revolving credit, and accepts on-demand and fixed term deposits from customers. &#9679; Nu Invest Corretora de Valores S.A. (&quot;Nu Invest&quot;) is an indirect subsidiary acquired in June 2021, domiciled in Brazil, and is a digital investment broker dealer. &#9679; Nu Distribuidora de Titulos e Valores Mobiliarios Ltda. (&quot;Nu DTVM&quot;) is an indirect subsidiary that executes securities brokerage activities in Brazil. &#9679; Nu M&eacute;xico Financiera, S.A. de C.V., S.F.P. (&quot;Nu Financiera&quot;) is an indirect subsidiary domiciled in Mexico. Nu Financiera is engaged in the issuance and administration of credit cards and payment transfers through a prepaid account. It commenced operations in the Mexican market in November 2022 and officially launched in December 2022. The credit card has similar characteristics to the Brazilian operation: an international credit card, with no annual fee, under the Mastercard banner, 100% managed by a digital app on a smartphone. &nbsp; 12 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &#9679; Nu Colombia S.A. (&#8220;Nu Colombia&#8221;) is an indirect subsidiary domiciled in Colombia, with operations related to credit cards, which was launched in September 2020. On August 10, 2022, the Financial Superintendence of Colombia (&quot;SFC&quot;) approved the Group's request to incorporate a financing company in Colombia, Nu Colombia Compa&ntilde;&iacute;a de Financiamiento S.A (&quot;Nu Colombia Financiamiento&quot;) (&quot;Incorporation License&quot;). Nu Colombia Financiamiento requested the license to operate as a financial company, which is still pending approval. If the request is approved, it will enable Nu Colombia to offer deposit products in the future, amongst other financial products. The Company and its consolidated subsidiaries are referred to in these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements as the &#8220;Group&#8221; or &quot;Nu&#8221;. &nbsp; The business plan of Nu provides for the continued growth of its Brazilian, Mexican, and Colombian operations, not only related to existing businesses, such as credit cards, personal loans, investments, and insurance, but also complemented by the launch of new products. Accordingly, these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements were prepared based on the assumption of the Group continuing as a going concern. &nbsp; The business is affected by customer behavior throughout the year and demonstrates seasonality effects. Historically, the Group benefited from a higher volume of transactions and related revenue in the fourth quarter of the year due to the holiday season. However, the growth has masked this seasonality in the past, and this may become more pronounced in the future. &nbsp; The Company&#8217;s Board authorized the issuance of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements on May 15, 2023. &nbsp; a) Level III BDR Program discontinuation &nbsp; On April 5, 2023 the Board of Directors decided to resubmit its plan for the voluntary discontinuance of its Level III BDRs Program, having approved the presentation of a new plan which would result in the cancellation of the Level III BDRs Program with the CVM; and, following this, the cancellation of the Company's registration with the CVM as a foreign public issuer of category &quot;A&quot; securities (&quot;New Plan&quot;). The New Plan is being submitted by the Company to B3 and CVM for further approval. If approved in the proposed format, the New Plan provides that the current holders of the BDRs must decide between: (i) remaining as the Company&#8217;s shareholder through the receipt of class A ordinary shares traded on the NYSE, with certain conditions that need to be met; (ii) remaining as holders of the Company's BDRs through the receipt of Unsponsored Level I BDRs; or (iii) if no declaration is made, the Company will sell the underlying shares on NYSE and former holders will receive the equivalent amount (&quot;Sales Facility&quot;). &nbsp; &nbsp; 13 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; b) Composition of goodwill and intangible assets shown in the consolidated statements of financial position &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Goodwill &nbsp; Intangible assets &nbsp; Goodwill &nbsp; Intangible assets Intangibles related to acquisitions &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Easynvest's acquisition &nbsp; 381,213 &nbsp; 38,609 &nbsp; 381,125 &nbsp; 40,263 Cognitect's acquisition &nbsp; 831 &nbsp; 2,414 &nbsp; 831 &nbsp; 2,673 Spin Pay's acquisition &nbsp; 5,060 &nbsp; 5,441 &nbsp; 5,060 &nbsp; 6,044 Olivia's acquisition &nbsp; 10,381 &nbsp; 31,561 &nbsp; 10,381 &nbsp; 33,397 Other intangible assets (i) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 137,277 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 99,787 Total &nbsp; 397,485 &nbsp; 215,302 &nbsp; 397,397 &nbsp; 182,164 (i) Mainly refers to the capitalization of software development costs. &nbsp; c) NuCoin &nbsp; In February 2023, Nu initiated the distribution of NuCoin, which is the native crypto token issued from Nu that enables the loyalty network (&quot;Nucoin Network&quot;) between Nu and its customers. Over time, Nu aims to have other sponsoring companies (&#8220;Sponsors&#8221;) that commit to use Nucoin as their loyalty program. These Sponsors will be entitled to a certain number of Nucoins to distribute to their customers, and will be required to offer benefits to Nucoins&#8217; holders to incentivize the network adoption and increase the overall utility to the community. &nbsp; &nbsp; 2. STATEMENT OF COMPLIANCE &nbsp; These unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements do not include all the information required for a complete set of financial statements prepared in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards (&quot;IFRS&#8221;) as issued by the International Accounting Standard Board (&#8220;IASB&#8221;). However, selected condensed explanatory notes are included to explain events and transactions that are significant to understanding the changes in the Company&#8217;s financial position and performance since the issuance of its last annual financial statements. &nbsp; The Group&#8217;s unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34 - Interim Financial Reporting issued by IASB. Accordingly, this report is to be read in conjunction with the annual consolidated financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2022 (the &quot;Annual Financial Statements&#8221;). &nbsp; a) Functional currency and foreign currency translation &nbsp; The presentation of the functional currency and foreign currency translation disclosed in note 2a. of the Annual Financial Statements remain valid for these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements. &nbsp; 14 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The functional currency for Nu Holdings and the presentation currency of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements is the US Dollar (&#8220;US$&#8221;). The functional currency of the Brazilian operating entities is the Brazilian real, for the Mexican entities, Mexican peso and for the Colombian entity, the Colombian peso. &nbsp; The financial statements of the foreign subsidiaries held in functional currencies that are not US$ are translated into US$, and the exchange differences arising from the translation to US$ of the financial statements denominated in functional currencies other than the US$ are recognized in the consolidated statements of comprehensive income or loss (OCI) as an item that may be reclassified to profit or loss within &#8220;currency translation on foreign entities&#8221;. &nbsp; b) New or revised accounting pronouncements adopted in 2023 &nbsp; The following new or revised standards have been issued by IASB, were effective for the period covered by these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements, and had no significant impact. &#9679; Disclosure of Accounting Policies (Amendments to IAS 1 and IFRS Practice Statement 2); &#9679; Definition of Accounting Estimates (Amendments to IAS 8); &#9679; Deferred Tax related to Assets and Liabilities arising from a Single Transaction (Amendments to IAS 12); and c) Other new standards and interpretations not yet effective &#9679; Non-current Liabilities with Covenants (Amendments to IAS 1). Management does not expect the adoption of the amendments described above to have a significant impact, other than additional disclosures, on the consolidated financial statements. &nbsp; &nbsp; 3. BASIS OF CONSOLIDATION &nbsp; These unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements include the accounting balances of Nu Holdings and all those subsidiaries over which the Company exercises control, directly or indirectly. Control is achieved where the Company has (i) power over the investee; (ii) is exposed, or has rights, to variable returns from its involvement with the investee; and (iii) can use its power to affect its profits. The Company re-assesses whether it maintains control of an investee if facts and circumstances indicate that there are changes to one or more of the three above mentioned elements of control. The consolidation of a subsidiary begins when the Company obtains control over it and ceases when the Company loses control over it. Assets, liabilities, income, and expenses of a subsidiary acquired or disposed of during the reporting period are included in the unaudited interim condensed consolidated statements of profit or loss from the date the Company gains control until the date the Company ceases to control the subsidiary. &nbsp; &nbsp; 15 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The financial information of the subsidiaries was prepared in the same period as the Company and consistent accounting policies were applied. The financial statements of the subsidiaries are fully consolidated with those of the Company. Accordingly, all balances, transactions and any unrealized income and expenses arising between consolidated entities are eliminated in the consolidation, except for foreign-currency gain and losses on translation of intercompany loans. Profit or loss and each component of other comprehensive income or loss are attributed to the shareholders of the parent and to the non-controlling interests, when applicable. The subsidiaries below are the most relevant entities included in these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements: Entity &nbsp; Control &nbsp; Principal activities &nbsp; Functional currency &nbsp; Country &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 Nu Colombia S.A. (&#8220;Nu Colombia&#8221;) &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Credit card operations &nbsp; COP &nbsp; Colombia &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% Nu Pagamentos S.A. - Institui&ccedil;&atilde;o de Pagamentos (&#8220;Nu Pagamentos&#8221;) &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Credit card and prepaid account operations &nbsp; BRL &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% Nu Financeira S.A. &#8211; SCFI (&#8220;Nu Financeira&#8221;) &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Loan operations &nbsp; BRL &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% Nu Distribuidora de Titulos e Valores Mobiliarios Ltda. (&quot;Nu DTVM&quot;) &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Securities distribution &nbsp; BRL &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% Nu Invest Corretora de Valores S.A (&quot;Nu Invest&quot;) - former &#8220;Easynvest TCV&quot; &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Investment platform &nbsp; BRL &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% Nu M&eacute;xico Financiera, S.A. de C.V., S.F.P. (&quot;Nu Financiera&quot;) - former &#8220;Akala&#8221; &nbsp; Indirect &nbsp; Multiple purpose financial company &nbsp; MXN &nbsp; Mexico &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; 100% &nbsp; In addition, the Company consolidated the following investment fund in which the Group&#8217;s companies hold a substantial interest or the entirety of the interests and are therefore exposed, or have rights, to variable returns and have the ability to affect those returns through power over the entity: &nbsp; Name of the entity &nbsp; Country Fundo de Investimento Ostrum Soberano Renda Fixa Referenciado DI (&#8220;Fundo Ostrum&#8221;) &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; Nu Pagamentos, Nu Financeira, Nu DTVM and Nu Invest, Brazilian subsidiaries, are regulated by the Brazilian Central Bank (&#8220;BACEN&#8221;), Nu M&eacute;xico Financiera, S.A. de C.V., S.F.P. (&quot;Nu Financiera&quot;), a Mexican subsidiary, is regulated by both the Mexican Central Bank (&quot;BANXICO&quot;) and Mexican National Banking and Stock Commission (&#8220;CNBV&#8221;) and Nu Colombia, a Colombian subsidiary, is regulated by Industry and Commerce Superintendency, and as such, there are some regulatory requirements that restrict the ability of the Group to access and transfer assets freely to or from these entities within the Group and to settle liabilities of the Group. &nbsp; &nbsp; 4. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING POLICIES &nbsp; The significant accounting policies adopted by the Group in the preparation of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements are consistent with those adopted and disclosed in the Annual Financial Statements and therefore should be read in conjunction. &nbsp; 16 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 5. SIGNIFICANT ACCOUNTING JUDGMENTS, ESTIMATES AND ASSUMPTIONS &nbsp; Use of estimates and judgments &nbsp; The preparation of financial statements requires judgments, estimates, and assumptions from management that affect the application of accounting policies, and reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues, and expenses. Actual results may differ from these estimates, and estimates and assumptions are reviewed on a periodic basis. Revisions to the estimates are recognized prospectively. &nbsp; The significant assumptions and estimates used in the preparation of these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements for the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 were the same as those adopted in the Annual Financial Statements. &nbsp; Credit losses on financial instruments &nbsp; The Group recognizes a loss allowance for expected credit losses on credit cards and loans receivables that represents management&#8217;s best estimate of allowance as of each reporting date. &nbsp; Management performs an analysis of the credit card and loan amounts to determine if credit losses have occurred and to assess the adequacy of the allowance based on historical and current trends as well as other factors affecting credit losses. &nbsp; Key areas of judgment &nbsp; The critical judgments made by management in applying the expected credit losses (ECL) allowance methodology are: a) Definition of default; b) Forward-looking information used for the projection of macroeconomic scenarios; c) Probability weights of future scenarios; d) Definition of significant increase in credit risk and lifetime; and e) Look-back period, used for parameters estimation (probability of default - PD, exposure at default - EAD and loss given default - LGD). Sensitivity analysis &nbsp; On March 31, 2023, the probability weighted ECL allowance totaled US$1,631,939 of which US$1,316,028 related to credit card operations and US$315,911 to loans. The ECL allowance is sensitive to the methodology, assumptions and estimations underlying its calculation. One key assumption is the probability weighting of the macroeconomic scenarios between upside, base and downside as the carrying amount of the credit loss allowance is determined based on the weighted average of these scenarios. The table below illustrates the ECL that would have arisen if management had applied a 100% weighting to each macroeconomic scenario. &nbsp; &nbsp; 17 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Weighted average &nbsp; Upside &nbsp; Base case &nbsp; Downside &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Credit card and lending ECL &nbsp; 1,631,939 &nbsp; 1,523,870 &nbsp; 1,609,498 &nbsp; 1,764,516 &nbsp; &nbsp; 6. INCOME AND RELATED EXPENSES &nbsp; a) Interest income and gains (losses) on financial instruments &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 03/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interest income &#8211; credit card &nbsp; 447,696 &nbsp; 166,140 Interest income - lending &nbsp; 286,943 &nbsp; 194,147 Interest income &#8211; other assets at amortized cost &nbsp; 154,163 &nbsp; 40,946 Interest income &#8211; other receivables &nbsp; 86,971 &nbsp; 23,380 Interest income and gains (losses) on financial instruments at fair value &nbsp; 279,681 &nbsp; 194,830 Financial assets at fair value &nbsp; 271,194 &nbsp; 194,900 Other &nbsp; 8,487 &nbsp; (70) Total interest income and gains (losses) on financial instruments &nbsp; 1,255,454 &nbsp; 619,443 &nbsp; The interest income presented above from credit card, lending, other assets at amortized cost and other receivables represents interest revenue calculated using the effective interest method. Financial assets at fair value comprises interest and the fair value changes on financial assets at fair value. &nbsp; b) Fee and commission income &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 03/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interchange fees &nbsp; 265,380 &nbsp; 189,506 Recharge fees &nbsp; 25,050 &nbsp; 15,945 Rewards revenue &nbsp; 5,547 &nbsp; 6,332 Late fees &nbsp; 36,359 &nbsp; 20,701 Other fee and commission income &nbsp; 30,877 &nbsp; 25,340 Total fee and commission income &nbsp; 363,213 &nbsp; 257,824 &nbsp; Fee and commission income are presented by fee types that reflect the nature of the services offered by the Group. Recharge fees comprise the selling price of telecom prepaid credits to customers, net of acquisition costs. &nbsp; On September 26, 2022, the Brazilian Central Bank (&#8220;BACEN&#8221;) issued Resolution No 246 (&quot;Resolution 246&quot;), which established that the maximum limit for the interchange fee levied on all prepaid card transactions in Brazil will be 0.70%. The new rules become effective on April 1, 2023. &nbsp; &nbsp; 18 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. EARNINGS (LOSS) PER SHARE &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 03/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Earnings (loss) attributable to shareholders of the parent company &nbsp; 141,751 &nbsp; (45,101) Weighted average outstanding shares - ordinary shares - basic (thousands) &nbsp; 4,709,469 &nbsp; 4,660,405 Adjustment for the basic earnings per shares: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deferred M&amp;A shares that will be issued based on the passage of time only &nbsp; 36 &nbsp; - Weighted average outstanding shares - ordinary shares - basic (thousands) &nbsp; 4,709,505 &nbsp; 4,660,405 Adjustment for the diluted earnings per share : &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Share based payment &nbsp; 104,052 &nbsp; - Business acquisition &nbsp; 4,643 &nbsp; - Total weighted average of ordinary outstanding shares for diluted EPS (in thousands of shares) &nbsp; 4,818,200 &nbsp; 4,660,405 Earnings (loss) per share &#8211; basic (US$) &nbsp; 0.0301 &nbsp; (0.0097) Earnings (loss) per share &#8211; diluted (US$) &nbsp; 0.0294 &nbsp; (0.0097) Antidilutive instruments not considered in the weighted number of shares (in thousands of shares) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 326,192 The Company has instruments that will become common shares upon exercise, acquisition, conversion (SOPs and RSUs described in note 10), or satisfaction of specific business combinations conditions (described in note 1). As of March 31, 2022, these instruments were not included in the weighted number of shares for diluted earnings per share because they would be antidilutive. The anti-dilutive instruments not considered in the weighted number of shares, for the periods presenting negative results, correspond to the total number of shares that could be converted into ordinary shares. &nbsp; 21 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 10. SHARE-BASED PAYMENTS &nbsp; a) Share settled awards &nbsp; The Group&#8217;s employee incentives include share settled awards in the form of stock, offering them the opportunity to purchase ordinary shares by exercising options (Stock Options &#8211; &#8220;SOPs&#8221;), receiving ordinary shares (Restricted Stock Units &#8211; &#8220;RSUs&#8221;) upon vesting, and receiving shares upon the achievement of market conditions and passage of time (&quot;Awards&quot;). &nbsp; The cost of the employee services received with respect to the SOPs and RSUs granted is recognized in the statement of profit or loss over the period that the employee provides services and according to the vesting conditions. The Group also issued Awards in 2020 that grant shares upon the achievement of market conditions related to the valuation of the Company, the Awards issued in 2021 were canceled at the end of 2022. RSUs incentive was implemented in 2020 and is the main incentive since then. &nbsp; There were no changes to the terms and conditions of the SOPs and RSUs after the grant date. The changes in the number of SOPs and RSUs are as follows. WAEP is the weighted average exercise price and WAGDFV is the weighted average fair value at the grant date. &nbsp; &nbsp; SOPs 03/31/2023 &nbsp; WAEP (US$) &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; WAEP (US$) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Outstanding on January 1 101,276,327 &nbsp; 0.72 &nbsp; 143,889,439 &nbsp; 0.55 Exercised during the period (10,207,564) &nbsp; 0.13 &nbsp; (37,095,966) &nbsp; 0.12 Forfeited during the period (1,409,572) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; (5,517,146) &nbsp; &nbsp; Outstanding on March 31 / December 31 89,659,191 &nbsp; 0.78 &nbsp; 101,276,327 &nbsp; 0.72 Exercisable on March 31 / December 31 74,708,715 &nbsp; 0.63 &nbsp; 81,813,095 &nbsp; 0.55 &nbsp; RSUs 03/31/2023 &nbsp; WAGDFV (US$) &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; WAGDFV (US$) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Outstanding on January 1 72,401,895 &nbsp; 5.46 &nbsp; 80,924,937 &nbsp; 4.82 Granted during the period 29,717,517 &nbsp; 4.52 &nbsp; 32,294,522 &nbsp; 5.47 Vested during the period (6,387,171) &nbsp; 4.33 &nbsp; (27,322,614) &nbsp; 3.64 Forfeited during the period (4,509,435) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; (13,494,950) &nbsp; &nbsp; Outstanding on March 31 / December 31 91,222,806 &nbsp; 5.21 &nbsp; 72,401,895 &nbsp; 5.46 &nbsp; The following tables present the total amount of share-based compensation granted for the three month period ended March 31, 2023 and March 31, 2022, and the provision for taxes as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022. &nbsp; &nbsp; 22 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Cash and cash equivalents &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Reverse repurchase agreement in foreign currency 33,201 &nbsp; 59,519 Short-term investments 98,547 &nbsp; 153,743 Voluntary deposits at central banks 2,472,575 &nbsp; 2,451,150 Bank balances 1,705,630 &nbsp; 1,506,727 Other cash and cash equivalents 543 &nbsp; 1,177 Total 4,310,496 &nbsp; 4,172,316 &nbsp; Cash and cash equivalents are held to meet short-term cash needs and include deposits with banks and other short-term highly liquid investments with original maturities of three-months or less and with an immaterial risk of change in value. &nbsp; The reverse repurchase agreements and short-term investments are mainly in Brazilian Reais, and the average rate of remuneration as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, is 99.9% and 99% of the Brazilian CDI rate, which is set daily and represents the average rate at which Brazilian banks were willing to borrow/lend to each other for one day. &nbsp; Voluntary deposits at central banks are deposits made by the subsidiary Nu Financeira at the Brazilian Central Bank, the average rate of remuneration as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, is 100% of the Brazilian CDI rate, and are considered as cash and cash equivalents as they mature in one business day. &nbsp; 23 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12. SECURITIES &nbsp; a) Financial instruments at fair value through profit and loss (&quot;FVTPL&quot;) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Breakdown by maturity &nbsp; &nbsp; Financial instruments at FVTPL &nbsp; Amortized Cost &nbsp; Fair Value &nbsp; No maturity &nbsp; Up to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Fair Value Government bonds &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 1,368,964 &nbsp; 1,353,651 &nbsp; 16,421 &nbsp; 353,356 &nbsp; 983,874 &nbsp; 1,552,457 Total financial instruments at FVTOCI &nbsp; 7,924,744 &nbsp; 7,916,143 &nbsp; 16,421 &nbsp; 3,062,871 &nbsp; 4,836,851 &nbsp; 9,947,138 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Amounts in &nbsp; Amounts in Financial instruments at FVTOCI &nbsp; Original Currency &nbsp; US$ &nbsp; Original Currency &nbsp; US$ Currency: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Brazilian Reais &nbsp; 34,354,546 &nbsp; 6,785,279 &nbsp; 45,527,868 &nbsp; 8,622,049 U.S. Dollars &nbsp; 1,129,488 &nbsp; 1,129,488 &nbsp; 1,323,707 &nbsp; 1,323,707 Others &nbsp; 24,832 &nbsp; 1,376 &nbsp; 26,949 &nbsp; 1,382 Total &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 7,916,143 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 9,947,138 &nbsp; (i) Includes US$1,999,710 (US$2,252,464 on December 31, 2022) held by the subsidiaries for regulatory purposes, as required by the Brazilian Central Bank. It also includes Brazilian government securities margins pledged by the Group for transactions on the Brazilian stock exchange in the amount of US$129,924 (US$160,485 on December 31, 2022). Government bonds are classified as Level 1 in the fair value hierarchy, as described in note 26. &nbsp; &nbsp; 25 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 13. CREDIT CARD RECEIVABLES &nbsp; a) Composition of receivables &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Receivables - current (i) &nbsp; 4,666,175 &nbsp; 4,236,235 Receivables - installments (i) &nbsp; 4,882,951 &nbsp; 4,259,979 Receivables - revolving (ii) &nbsp; 905,471 &nbsp; 770,011 Total receivables &nbsp; 10,454,597 &nbsp; 9,266,225 Fair value adjustment - portfolio hedge (note 18) &nbsp; (18) &nbsp; (51) Total &nbsp; 10,454,579 &nbsp; 9,266,174 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Credit card ECL allowance &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Presented as deduction of receivables &nbsp; (1,296,127) &nbsp; (1,033,102) Presented as &quot;Other liabilities&quot; &nbsp; (19,901) &nbsp; (17,566) Total credit card ECL allowance &nbsp; (1,316,028) &nbsp; (1,050,668) Receivables, net &nbsp; 9,138,551 &nbsp; 8,215,506 Total receivables presented as assets &nbsp; 9,158,452 &nbsp; 8,233,072 &nbsp; (i) &quot;Receivables - current&quot; is related to purchases made and single installment pix (BACEN instant payments) financing by customers due on the next credit card billing date. &#8220;Receivables - installments&#8221; is related to purchases in installments which are financed by the merchant. Credit card receivables can be paid by our clients in up to 12, 24 and 36 monthly installments in Brazil, Mexico and Colombia, respectively. The cardholder&#8217;s credit limit is initially reduced by the total amount and the installments become due and payable on the cardholder's subsequent monthly credit card statement. The Group makes the corresponding payments to the credit card network (see note 21) following a similar schedule. As receipts and payments are aligned, the Group does not incur significant financing costs with this product, however it is exposed to the credit risk of the cardholder as it is obliged to make the payments to the credit card network even if the cardholder does not pay. &#8220;Receivables - installments&#8221; also includes the amounts of credit card bills not fully paid by the customers and that have been converted into payments in installments with a fixed interest rate ( fatura parcelada ), in addition to bill financing, which comprise bills paid in installments through the credit card, and pix financing in more than one installment. &nbsp; (ii) &quot;Receivables - revolving&quot; is related to the amounts due from customers that have not paid in full their credit card bill. Customers may request to convert these receivables into loans to be paid in installments. In accordance with Brazilian regulation, revolving balances that are outstanding for more than 2 months are mandatorily converted into fatura parcelada - a type of installment loan which is settled through the customer&#8217;s monthly credit card bills . &nbsp; &nbsp; 26 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; b) Breakdown by maturity &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Amount &nbsp; % &nbsp; Amount &nbsp; % Installments not overdue due in: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;= 30 days &nbsp; 4,601,823 &nbsp; 44.0% &nbsp; 4,036,414 &nbsp; 43.6% 30 &lt; 60 days &nbsp; 1,737,186 &nbsp; 16.6% &nbsp; 1,604,056 &nbsp; 17.3% &gt; 60 days &nbsp; 3,100,191 &nbsp; 29.7% &nbsp; 2,823,966 &nbsp; 30.5% Total not overdue installments &nbsp; 9,439,200 &nbsp; 90.3% &nbsp; 8,464,436 &nbsp; 91.3% &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Installments overdue by: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;= 30 days &nbsp; 315,549 &nbsp; 3.0% &nbsp; 237,531 &nbsp; 2.6% 30 &lt; 60 days &nbsp; 126,330 &nbsp; 1.2% &nbsp; 91,604 &nbsp; 1.0% 60 &lt; 90 days &nbsp; 89,257 &nbsp; 0.9% &nbsp; 74,917 &nbsp; 0.8% &gt; 90 days &nbsp; 484,261 &nbsp; 4.6% &nbsp; 397,737 &nbsp; 4.3% Total overdue installments &nbsp; 1,015,397 &nbsp; 9.7% &nbsp; 801,789 &nbsp; 8.7% Total &nbsp; 10,454,597 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; 9,266,225 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; Overdue installments consist mainly of revolving balances, and not overdue installments consist mainly of current receivables and future bill installments ( parcelado ). &nbsp; c) Credit loss allowance - by stages &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023, the credit card ECL allowance totaled US$1,316,028 (US$1,050,668 as of December 31, 2022). The provision is estimated using modeling techniques, consistently applied, and is sensitive to the methods, assumptions, and risk parameters underlying its calculation. &nbsp; The amount that the credit loss allowance represents in comparison to the Group&#8217;s gross receivables (the coverage ratio) is also monitored, to anticipate trends that could indicate credit risk increases. This metric is considered a key risk indicator and it is monitored across multiple committees, supporting the decision-making process and is discussed in the credit forums. &nbsp; All receivables are classified through stages, where: (i) stage 1 include all receivables not classified in stages 2 and 3; (ii) stage 2 is primarily related to all receivables more than 30 (thirty), but less than 90 (ninety), days in arrears, or with an increase in client's behavior risk score compared to the time of the origination; and (iii) stage 3 when receivables are more than 90 (ninety) days in arrears, or there are indications that the financial asset will not be fully paid without a collateral or financial guarantee. &nbsp; The majority of the Group's credit card portfolio was classified as stage 1, followed by stages 2 and 3, respectively as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022. The proportion of stage 3 exposures increased to 6.9% on March 31, 2023 from 6.5% on December 31, 2022. The stage 3 movement is primarily due to credit expansions done in the past which are maturing in the portfolio, along with delinquency seasonality. &nbsp; 27 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Gross Exposures &nbsp; % &nbsp; Credit Loss Allowance &nbsp; % &nbsp; Coverage Ratio (%) Strong (PD &lt; 5%) &nbsp; 6,097,909 &nbsp; 65.8% &nbsp; 113,780 &nbsp; 10.8% &nbsp; 1.9% Stage 1 &nbsp; 6,081,551 &nbsp; 99.7% &nbsp; 113,525 &nbsp; 99.8% &nbsp; 1.9% Stage 2 &nbsp; 16,358 &nbsp; 0.3% &nbsp; 255 &nbsp; 0.2% &nbsp; 1.6% &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Satisfactory (5% &lt;= PD &lt;= 20%) &nbsp; 1,477,414 &nbsp; 15.9% &nbsp; 118,825 &nbsp; 11.2% &nbsp; 8.0% Stage 1 &nbsp; 1,227,610 &nbsp; 83.1% &nbsp; 100,190 &nbsp; 84.3% &nbsp; 8.2% Stage 2 &nbsp; 249,804 &nbsp; 16.9% &nbsp; 18,635 &nbsp; 15.7% &nbsp; 7.5% &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Higher Risk (PD &gt; 20%) &nbsp; 1,690,902 &nbsp; 18.3% &nbsp; 818,063 &nbsp; 78.0% &nbsp; 48.4% Stage 1 &nbsp; 441,109 &nbsp; 26.1% &nbsp; 109,255 &nbsp; 13.4% &nbsp; 24.8% Stage 2 &nbsp; 651,016 &nbsp; 38.5% &nbsp; 235,291 &nbsp; 28.8% &nbsp; 36.1% Stage 3 &nbsp; 598,777 &nbsp; 35.4% &nbsp; 473,517 &nbsp; 57.9% &nbsp; 79.1% Total &nbsp; 9,266,225 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; 1,050,668 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; 11.3% &nbsp; When compared to December 31, 2022, a change in the credit quality distribution is observed, with relative exposure moving to higher PD stages. This movement is explained in the item c) Credit loss allowance - by stages and changes to models. There is still a significant concentration of receivables at stage 1 based on credit quality. Receivables with satisfactory risk are distributed between stages 1 and 2, mostly at stage 1. &nbsp; Defaulted assets at stage 3 are classified as higher risk. There is also a large proportion of stage 2 exposures classified as higher risk. Stage 1 receivables classified as higher risk are those customers with low credit risk scores. &nbsp; 29 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. ECL effects presented in the table were calculated as if risk parameters at the beginning of the period were applied. &nbsp; (b) Reflects the movements in exposure of accounts that already existed in the beginning of the period, as increase in credit limits. ECL effects were calculated as if risk parameters of the exposures at the beginning of the period were applied. &nbsp; (c) Relates to methodology changes that occurred during the period, according to the Group&#8217;s processes of model monitoring. &nbsp; The following tables present changes in the gross carrying amount of the credit card portfolio to demonstrate the effects of the changes in the loss allowance for the same portfolio as discussed above. &#8220;Net change of gross carrying amount&#8221; includes acquisitions, payments, and interest accruals. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Stage 1 &nbsp; Stage 2 &nbsp; Stage 3 &nbsp; Total Gross carrying amount at beginning of period &nbsp; 7,750,270 &nbsp; 917,178 &nbsp; 598,777 &nbsp; 9,266,225 Transfers from Stage 1 to Stage 2 &nbsp; (440,771) &nbsp; 440,771 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - Transfers from Stage 2 to Stage 1 &nbsp; 199,883 &nbsp; (199,883) &nbsp; - &nbsp; - Transfers to Stage 3 &nbsp; (53,612) &nbsp; (227,005) &nbsp; 280,617 &nbsp; - Transfers from Stage 3 &nbsp; 5,156 &nbsp; 3,580 &nbsp; (8,736) &nbsp; - Write-offs &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; (174,938) &nbsp; (174,938) Net change of gross carrying amount &nbsp; 850,562 &nbsp; 73,470 &nbsp; (3,249) &nbsp; 920,783 Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; 367,435 &nbsp; 44,752 &nbsp; 30,340 &nbsp; 442,527 Gross carrying amount at end of the period &nbsp; 8,678,923 &nbsp; 1,052,863 &nbsp; 722,811 &nbsp; 10,454,597 &nbsp; &nbsp; 31 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. LOANS TO CUSTOMERS &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 Lending to individuals &nbsp; 2,337,419 &nbsp; 1,976,499 Loan ECL allowance &nbsp; (315,911) &nbsp; (300,223) Total receivables &nbsp; 2,021,508 &nbsp; 1,676,276 Fair value adjustment - portfolio hedge (note 18) &nbsp; (1,317) &nbsp; (2,836) Total &nbsp; 2,020,191 &nbsp; 1,673,440 &nbsp; &nbsp; 32 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; a) Breakdown by maturity &nbsp; The following table shows loans to customers by maturity on March 31, 2023, and December 31 2022, considering each installment individually. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Amount &nbsp; % &nbsp; Amount &nbsp; % Installments not overdue due in: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Less than 1 year &nbsp; 2,032,053 &nbsp; 86.9% &nbsp; 1,697,288 &nbsp; 85.9% Between 1 and 5 years &nbsp; 213,265 &nbsp; 9.1% &nbsp; 198,533 &nbsp; 10.0% Total not overdue installments &nbsp; 2,245,318 &nbsp; 96.0% &nbsp; 1,895,821 &nbsp; 95.9% &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Installments overdue by: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &lt;= 30 days &nbsp; 35,570 &nbsp; 1.5% &nbsp; 30,509 &nbsp; 1.5% 30 &lt; 60 days &nbsp; 20,888 &nbsp; 1.0% &nbsp; 18,191 &nbsp; 1.0% 60 &lt; 90 days &nbsp; 11,848 &nbsp; 0.5% &nbsp; 13,315 &nbsp; 0.7% &gt; 90 days &nbsp; 23,795 &nbsp; 1.0% &nbsp; 18,663 &nbsp; 0.9% Total overdue installments &nbsp; 92,101 &nbsp; 4.0% &nbsp; 80,678 &nbsp; 4.1% Total &nbsp; 2,337,419 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; 1,976,499 &nbsp; 100.0% &nbsp; b) Credit loss allowance - by stages &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023, the loans to customers ECL allowance totaled US$315,911 (US$300,223 as of December 31, 2022). The provision is estimated using modeling techniques, consistently applied, which is sensitive to the methods, assumptions, and risk parameters underlying its calculation. &nbsp; The amount that the credit loss allowance represents in comparison to the Group&#8217;s gross receivables (the coverage ratio) is also monitored, to anticipate trends that could indicate credit risk increases. This metric is considered a key risk indicator and it is monitored across multiple committees, supporting the decision-making process and is discussed in the credit forums. &nbsp; All receivables are classified through stages. The explanation of each stage is set out in the Company&#8217;s accounting policies, as disclosed in the annual consolidated financial statements as of December 31, 2022. &nbsp; The majority of the Group's loans to customers&#8217; portfolio was classified as stage 1, followed by stages 2 and 3, respectively as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022. The proportion of stage 1 exposures increased to 78.5% on March 31, 2023, from 77.0% on December 31, 2022. The stage 1 movement is primarily due to the growth of the portfolio into lower risk segments. &nbsp; &nbsp; 33 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. COMPULSORY AND OTHER DEPOSITS AT CENTRAL BANKS &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Compulsory deposits &nbsp; 2,159,408 &nbsp; 2,026,516 Reserve at BACEN &nbsp; 512,260 &nbsp; 751,503 Total &nbsp; 2,671,668 &nbsp; 2,778,019 &nbsp; Compulsory deposits are required by BACEN based on the amount of RDB held by Nu Financeira. &nbsp; Reserve at BACEN relates to the Instant Payments Account, which is required by BACEN to support instant payment operations. &nbsp; &nbsp; 16. OTHER RECEIVABLES &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Other receivables &nbsp; 1,078,801 &nbsp; 522,734 ECL Allowance - Other receivables &nbsp; (2,120) &nbsp; (1,064) Total &nbsp; 1,076,681 &nbsp; 521,670 &nbsp; Other receivables in the amount of US$1,078,801 (US$522,734 as of December 31, 2022), with an ECL allowance of US$2,120 (US$1,064 as of December 31, 2022), are related to the acquisition of credit card receivables from acquirers at a discount to face value. As of March 31, 2023 and 2022, the total amount of the Group's exposure was classified as stage 1 and there was no transfer between stages for either of the three-month periods ended March 31, 2023 and 2022. &nbsp; &nbsp; 38 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 17. OTHER ASSETS &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deferred expenses (i) &nbsp; 170,465 &nbsp; 157,439 Taxes recoverable &nbsp; 181,393 &nbsp; 245,967 Advances to suppliers and employees &nbsp; 21,303 &nbsp; 22,662 Prepaid expenses &nbsp; 73,234 &nbsp; 61,744 Judicial deposits (note 23) &nbsp; 19,781 &nbsp; 18,864 Other assets &nbsp; 34,049 &nbsp; 35,227 Total &nbsp; 500,225 &nbsp; 541,903 &nbsp; (i) Refers to credit card issuance costs, including printing, packing, and shipping costs, among others. The expenses are amortized based on the card&#8217;s useful life, adjusted for any cancellations. &nbsp; &nbsp; 39 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 18. DERIVATIVE FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS &nbsp; The Group executes transactions with derivative financial instruments, which are intended to meet its own needs to reduce its exposure to market, currency and interest-rate risks. The derivatives are classified as at fair value through profit or loss, except those in cash flow hedge accounting strategies, for which the effective portion of gains or losses on derivatives is recognized directly in other comprehensive income (loss). The management of these risks is conducted through determining limits, and the establishment of operating strategies. The derivative contracts are considered level 1, 2 or 3 in the fair value hierarchy and are used to hedge exposures, but hedge accounting is adopted only for forecasted transactions related to the cloud infrastructure and certain software licenses used by Nu (hedge of foreign currency risk), to hedge interest of the fixed rate credit portfolio (hedge of interest rate risk of portfolio) and to hedge the future cash disbursement related to highly probable future transactions and accrued liabilities for corporate and social security taxes at RSU vesting or SOP exercise, as shown below. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Fair values &nbsp; &nbsp; Notional amount &nbsp; Assets &nbsp; Liabilities Derivatives classified as fair value through profit or loss &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 398,955 &nbsp; 93 &nbsp; 4 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 143,572 &nbsp; 72 &nbsp; 885 Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; 10,488 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1 Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 26,736 &nbsp; 700 &nbsp; 8,402 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 166,600 &nbsp; 624 &nbsp; - Warrants (i) &nbsp; 100,000 &nbsp; 9,610 &nbsp; - &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Derivatives held for hedging &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Designated as cash flow hedge &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 189,895 &nbsp; 18 &nbsp; 1,024 Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 62,990 &nbsp; 3,489 &nbsp; - &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Designated as portfolio hedge &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; 1,147,279 &nbsp; 80 &nbsp; 28 Total &nbsp; 2,246,515 &nbsp; 14,686 &nbsp; 10,344 &nbsp; &nbsp; 40 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Fair values &nbsp; &nbsp; Notional amount &nbsp; Assets &nbsp; Liabilities Derivatives classified as fair value through profit or loss &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 792,559 &nbsp; 27 &nbsp; 105 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 111,634 &nbsp; 917 &nbsp; 51 Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; 10,056 &nbsp; 50 &nbsp; - Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 113,682 &nbsp; 11,228 &nbsp; 24 Warrants (i) &nbsp; 100,000 &nbsp; 27,908 &nbsp; - &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Derivatives held for hedging &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Designated as cash flow hedge &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 129,459 &nbsp; 1,209 &nbsp; 182 Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 89,726 &nbsp; 145 &nbsp; 9,017 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Designated as portfolio hedge &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; 1,551,521 &nbsp; 1 &nbsp; 46 Total &nbsp; 2,898,637 &nbsp; 41,485 &nbsp; 9,425 &nbsp; Futures contracts are traded on the B3, having B3 as the counterparty. The total value of margins pledged by the Group in transactions on the stock exchange is presented in note 12. &nbsp; Swaps of interest risk contracts are settled on a daily basis and are traded over the counter with financial institutions as counterparties. &nbsp; Nu Holdings entered into non-deliverable forward contracts to hedge intercompany loans with Nu Colombia in US dollars with a settlement in December 2023. &nbsp; Swap TRS contracts are settled only at maturity and are traded over the counter with financial institutions as counterparties, see more details in item d. &nbsp; (i) Warrants &nbsp; In September 2021, Nu entered into an agreement with Creditas Financial Solutions Ltd. (and/or its affiliates in Latin America, or together, &#8220;Creditas&#8221;) through which Nu will distribute certain financial products offered by Creditas to its customers in Latin America. These include affordable retail collateralized loans, such as home and auto equity loans, auto financing, motorcycle financing and payroll loans. &nbsp; The agreement also provided that Nu would invest in Creditas&#8217; securitization vehicles, becoming the holder of the senior quotas of the fund. As of March 31, 2023 the Company had a total of US$184,224 invested in Creditas&#8217; securitization vehicles presented as FVTOCI. &nbsp; &nbsp; 41 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In addition, Nu was granted warrants that provide the right to acquire an equity interest equivalent to up to 7.7% of Creditas, on a fully diluted basis, under a pre-agreed valuation, proportional to fifty percent of the amount invested in the securitization vehicles and products distributed. The notional of the warrants is US$100,000 and is presented in the table above. Nu can exercise the warrants at any time, but the expiration date is 2 years after the issuance date. &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023, the warrants' fair value was US$9,610 (US$27,908 as of December 31, 2022) calculated using a Black Scholes model, classified as level 3 on the fair value hierarchy, as shown in note 26. The Company recognized a fair value loss of US$18,298 during the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. The reduction in the warrant&#8217;s fair value resulted from updates in the assumptions used in the related option pricing model, including the reduction in the remaining exercise period of the warrants, which expire in September 2023. &nbsp; Breakdown by maturity &nbsp; The table below shows the breakdown by maturity of the notional amounts: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 3 months &nbsp; 3 to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 217,148 &nbsp; 104,929 &nbsp; 19,292 &nbsp; 341,369 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 333,467 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 333,467 Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 10,488 &nbsp; 10,488 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 166,600 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 166,600 Warrants &nbsp; - &nbsp; 100,000 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 100,000 Total assets &nbsp; 550,615 &nbsp; 371,529 &nbsp; 29,780 &nbsp; 951,924 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 89,726 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 89,726 Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 45,271 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 12,315 &nbsp; 57,586 DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; 579,390 &nbsp; 510,709 &nbsp; 57,180 &nbsp; 1,147,279 Total liabilities &nbsp; 714,387 &nbsp; 510,709 &nbsp; 69,495 &nbsp; 1,294,591 Total &nbsp; 1,265,002 &nbsp; 882,238 &nbsp; 99,275 &nbsp; 2,246,515 &nbsp; &nbsp; 42 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd.
