&nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 4,189 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 4,189 Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; - Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 2 &nbsp; 91 &nbsp; 93 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 90 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 90 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 624 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 624 Warrants &nbsp; 9,610 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 9,610 DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; 46 &nbsp; 34 &nbsp; 80 Total assets &nbsp; 14,561 &nbsp; 125 &nbsp; 14,686 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; - Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1 &nbsp; 1 Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 3 &nbsp; 1 &nbsp; 4 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 1,909 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,909 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 8,402 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 8,402 DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 28 &nbsp; 28 Total liabilities &nbsp; 10,314 &nbsp; 30 &nbsp; 10,344 &nbsp; &nbsp; 43 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 145 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 145 Interest rate contracts - Swap &nbsp; - &nbsp; 50 &nbsp; 50 Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 27 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 27 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 2,126 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2,126 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 11,228 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 11,228 Warrants &nbsp; - &nbsp; 27,908 &nbsp; 27,908 Interest rate contracts - Future - portfolio hedge &nbsp; 1 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1 Total assets &nbsp; 13,527 &nbsp; 27,958 &nbsp; 41,485 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity - Total Return Swap (TRS) &nbsp; 9,017 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 9,017 Interest rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 17 &nbsp; 88 &nbsp; 105 Exchange rate contracts - Future &nbsp; 233 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 233 Currency - Non-deliverable forward contract (NDF) &nbsp; 24 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 24 DI - Future - notes 13 and 14 &nbsp; 46 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 46 Total liabilities &nbsp; 9,337 &nbsp; 88 &nbsp; 9,425 &nbsp; Analysis of derivatives designated as hedges &nbsp; a) Hedge of foreign currency risk &nbsp; The Group is exposed to foreign currency risk on forecast transaction expenses, primarily related to the cloud infrastructure and certain software licenses used by Nu. The Group managed its exposures to the variability in cash flows of foreign currency forecasted transactions to movements in foreign exchange rates by entering into foreign exchange contracts (exchange futures). These instruments are entered into to match the cash flow profile of the estimated forecast transactions, and are exchange-traded and fair value movements are settled on a daily basis. &nbsp; The Group applies hedge accounting to the forecasted transactions related to its main cloud infrastructure contract and other expenses in foreign currency. The effectiveness is assessed monthly by analyzing the critical terms. The critical terms of the hedging instrument and the amount of the forecasted hedged transactions are significantly the same. Derivatives are generally rolled over monthly. They are expected to occur in the same fiscal month as the maturity date of the hedging instrument. Therefore, the hedge is expected to be effective. Subsequent assessments of effectiveness are performed by verifying and documenting whether the critical terms of the hedging instrument and forecasted hedged transaction have changed during the period in review and whether it remains probable. If there are no such changes in critical terms, the Group will continue to conclude that the hedging relationship is effective. Sources of ineffectiveness are differences in the amount and timing of forecast and actual payment of expenses. &nbsp; &nbsp; 44 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; Year ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at beginning of the period &nbsp; (2,610) &nbsp; 1,487 Fair value change recognized in OCI during the period &nbsp; (10,365) &nbsp; (20,924) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Total amount reclassified from cash flow hedge reserve to the statement of profit or loss during the period &nbsp; 2,801 &nbsp; 14,012 to &quot;Customer support and operation&quot; &nbsp; 2,352 &nbsp; 6,769 to &quot;General and administrative expenses&quot; &nbsp; 502 &nbsp; 7,778 Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; (53) &nbsp; (535) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deferred income taxes &nbsp; 3,026 &nbsp; 2,815 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at end of the period &nbsp; (7,148) &nbsp; (2,610) &nbsp; The future transactions that are the object of the hedge are: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 3 months &nbsp; 3 to 12 months &nbsp; Total &nbsp; Total Expected foreign currency transactions &nbsp; 71,387 &nbsp; 118,708 &nbsp; 190,095 &nbsp; 129,459 Total &nbsp; 71,387 &nbsp; 118,708 &nbsp; 190,095 &nbsp; 129,459 &nbsp; b) Hedge of portfolio's interest rate risk &nbsp; The Group holds portfolios of customers&#8217; lending and refinancing of credit cards receivables at fixed interest rates, which creates market risk due to changes in the Brazilian interbank deposits&#8217; (CDI) benchmark rate. Thus, to protect the fixed rate risk from CDI variation, the Group entered into future DI contracts to offset the market risk, and applied hedge accounting aiming to eliminate differences between the accounting measurement of its derivatives and hedged items which are adjusted to reflect changes in CDI. The Group&#8217;s overall hedging strategy is to reduce fair value changes of the part of the fixed rate portfolio as if they were floating rate instruments linked to the attributable benchmark rates. As such, in order to reflect the dynamic nature of the hedged portfolio, the strategy is to rebalance the future DI contracts and evaluate the allocated amount by the credit portfolio. Additionally, ineffectiveness could arise from the disparity between expected and actual prepayments (prepayment risk). &nbsp; &nbsp; 45 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In accordance with its hedging strategy, the Group calculates the DV01 (delta value of a basis point ) of the exposure and futures to identify the optimal hedging ratio, and monitors in a timely manner the hedge relationship, providing any rebalancing if needed. The need for the purchase or sale of new future DI contracts will be assessed, to counterbalance the hedged item&#8217;s market value adjustment, aiming to assure hedge effectiveness between 80% and 125%, as determined on hedge documentation. &nbsp; The effectiveness test for the hedge is done in a prospective and retrospective way. In the prospective test, the Group compares the impact of a 1 basis point parallel shift on the interest rate curve (DV01) on the hedged object and on the hedge instrument market value. For the retrospective test, the market-to-market value change since the inception of the hedged object is compared to the hedge instrument. In both cases, the hedge is considered effective if the correlation is between 80% and 125%. &nbsp; For designated and qualifying fair value hedges, the cumulative change in the fair value of the hedging derivative and of the hedged item attributable to the hedged risk is recognized in the consolidated statement of profit or loss in &quot;Interest income and gains (losses) on financial instruments - financial assets at fair value&quot;. In addition, the cumulative change in the fair value of the hedged item attributable to the hedged risk is recorded as part of the carrying value of the hedged item in the consolidated statement of financial position. &nbsp; Effectiveness ratio - changes in fair value &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Derivative object hedge &nbsp; Fair value adjustment to the hedge object &nbsp; Derivative hedge instrument &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Asset &nbsp; Liability &nbsp; Fair value variation &nbsp; Effectiveness Interest rate risk &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Interest rate contracts - Future - portfolio hedge - credit card &nbsp; 36,351 &nbsp; (18) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 6 &nbsp; 100.0% Interest rate contracts - Future - portfolio hedge - loan &nbsp; 701,042 &nbsp; (1,317) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 716 &nbsp; 99.0% Total &nbsp; 737,393 &nbsp; (1,335) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 722 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; c) Hedge of corporate and social security taxes over share-based compensation &nbsp; The Group's hedge strategy is to cover the future cash disbursement related to highly probable future transactions and accrued liabilities for corporate and social security taxes at RSU vesting or SOP exercise from the variation of the Company's share price volatility. The derivative financial instruments used to cover the exposure are total return swaps (&quot;TRS&quot;) in which one leg is indexed to the Company's stock price and the other leg is indexed to Secured Overnight Financing Rate (&quot;SOFR&quot;) plus spread. The stock fixed at the TRS is a weighted average price. The hedge was entered into by Nu Holdings and therefore there is no income tax effect. &nbsp; &nbsp; 46 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The Group applies the cash flow hedge for the hedge structure thus the market risk is replaced by an interest rate risk. The effectiveness assessment is performed monthly by (i) assessing the economic relationship between the hedged item and the hedging instrument; (ii) monitoring the credit risk impact in the hedge effectiveness; and (iii) maintaining and updating the hedging ratio. Given the possibility of forfeiture impacting the future cash forecast of the employee benefit plan, the Group manages exposures to keep the hedging level within an acceptable coverage. The derivative fair value is measured substantially based on the stock price which is also used in the measurement of the provision or payment for corporate and social security taxes. There is no expectation for a mismatch between the hedged item and hedging instrument at maturity other than the SOFR. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; Year ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at beginning of the period &nbsp; (4,876) &nbsp; - Fair value change recognized in OCI during the period &nbsp; 12,360 &nbsp; (8,871) Total amount reclassified from cash flow hedge reserve to the statement of profit or loss during the period (i) &nbsp; (5,675) &nbsp; 3,995 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at end of the period &nbsp; 1,809 &nbsp; (4,876) (i) Presented as share-based compensation in general and administrative expenses. Expected cash disbursement &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 1 year &nbsp; 1 to 3 years &nbsp; Above 3 years &nbsp; Total &nbsp; Total &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Expected cash disbursement for Corporate Social Contributions over Employee Income payments &nbsp; 38,914 &nbsp; 30,157 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 69,071 &nbsp; 59,058 Total &nbsp; 38,914 &nbsp; 30,157 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 69,071 &nbsp; 59,058 &nbsp; &nbsp; 19. INSTRUMENTS ELIGIBLE AS CAPITAL &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 Financial liabilities at fair value through profit or loss &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Instruments eligible as capital &nbsp; 2,932 &nbsp; 11,507 Total &nbsp; 2,932 &nbsp; 11,507 &nbsp; There were no defaults or breaches of instruments eligible as capital or on any financial liability during the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 and year ended December 31, 2022. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 47 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; In June 2019, the subsidiary Nu Financeira issued a subordinated financial note in the amount equivalent to US$18,824 at the issuance date, which was approved as Tier 2 capital by the Brazilian Central Bank in September 2019, for the purposes of calculation of regulatory capital. The note bears a fixed interest rate of 12.8%, matures in 2029, and is callable in 2024. &nbsp; The Group designated the instruments eligible as capital at fair value through profit (loss) at its initial recognition. The losses of fair value changes arising from its own credit risk in the amount of US$45 were recorded in other comprehensive income (gains of US$8,192 in the year ended December 31, 2022). All other fair value changes and interests in the amount of US$2,985 (US$7,310 in the year ended December 31, 2022) were recognized as profit (loss). &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; Year ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 Balance at beginning of the period &nbsp; 11,507 &nbsp; 12,056 Interest accrued, net of gain from repurchase &nbsp; (3,030) &nbsp; (882) Fair value changes &nbsp; 45 &nbsp; 8,192 Own credit transferred to OCI &nbsp; (45) &nbsp; (2,008) Repurchase &nbsp; (5,870) &nbsp; - Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; 325 &nbsp; (5,851) Balance at end of the period &nbsp; 2,932 &nbsp; 11,507 &nbsp; &nbsp; 20. FINANCIAL LIABILITIES AT AMORTIZED COST &#8211; DEPOSITS &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deposits by customers &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Bank receipt of deposits (RDB) &nbsp; 14,520,723 &nbsp; 14,273,959 Deposits in electronic money &nbsp; 1,236,940 &nbsp; 1,534,582 Total &nbsp; 15,757,663 &nbsp; 15,808,541 &nbsp; In June 2019, Nu Financeira's RDB was launched as an investment option in NuConta. After the compulsory deposits requirements (see note 15), unlike the deposits in electronic money, Nu may or may not invest the remaining resources from RDB&#8217;s deposits in government securities. They can be used as a financing source for the lending and credit card operations, instead. RDB&#8217;s deposits have guarantees from the Brazilian Deposit Guarantee Fund (&#8220;FGC&#8221;) and the return is 100% of the CDI as of the thirty-first day, also considering the retroactive yield from the first thirty days on the unused deposit balances, with the exception of 'money boxes' modality that has daily return. &nbsp; In September 2020, Nu Financeira launched a new investment option &#8211; a RDB with a defined future maturity date. In March 2023, RDBs had maturities of up to 27 months and a weighted average interest rate of 103% as of March 31, 2023 (and 104% on December 31, 2022) of the Brazilian CDI rate. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 48 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deposits in electronic money include NuConta (Brazil and Mexico) and Conta NuInvest amounts, the latter corresponding to on-demand deposits of the Groups&#8217; investment brokerage clients. In Brazil, those deposits are required by BACEN to be invested in Brazilian government bonds (see note 12b) and the return is also 100% of the CDI as of the thirty-first day, also considering the retroactive yield from the first thirty days on the unused deposit balances. In Mexico there is no requirement to invest the deposits in specific assets, they can be used as a financing source for the credit card operations, and the return is the Interbank Equilibrium Interest Rate &quot;TIIE&quot; - 2%, as of March 31, 2023.Deposits in electronic money through NuConta and part of the RDBs, correspond to customer deposits on-demand with daily maturity made in the prepaid account, denominated in Brazilian reais. &nbsp; Breakdown by maturity &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Deposits by customers &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deposits in electronic money &nbsp; 1,236,940 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,236,940 Bank receipt of deposits (RDB) &nbsp; 14,418,755 &nbsp; 101,968 &nbsp; 14,520,723 Total &nbsp; 15,655,695 &nbsp; 101,968 &nbsp; 15,757,663 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Deposits by customers &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deposits in electronic money &nbsp; 1,534,582 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,534,582 Bank receipt of deposits (RDB) &nbsp; 14,160,805 &nbsp; 113,154 &nbsp; 14,273,959 Total &nbsp; 15,695,387 &nbsp; 113,154 &nbsp; 15,808,541 &nbsp; &nbsp; 21. FINANCIAL LIABILITIES AT AMORTIZED COST &#8211; PAYABLES TO NETWORK &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Payables to credit card network (i) &nbsp; 6,781,841 &nbsp; 7,054,783 Payables to clearing houses &nbsp; 89,985 &nbsp; - Total &nbsp; 6,871,826 &nbsp; 7,054,783 &nbsp; (i) Corresponds to the amount payable to the acquirers related to credit and debit card transactions. Credit card payables are settled according to the transaction installments, substantially in up to 27 days for Brazilian transactions with no installments and 1 business day for international transactions. Sales in installments ( parcelado ) have monthly settlements, mostly, over a period of up to 12 months. For Mexican and Colombian operations, the amounts are settled in 1 business day. The segregation of the settlement is shown in the table below: &nbsp; &nbsp; 49 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Payables to credit card network &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 30 days &nbsp; 3,552,550 &nbsp; 3,829,398 30 to 90 days &nbsp; 1,710,811 &nbsp; 1,741,186 More than 90 days &nbsp; 1,518,480 &nbsp; 1,484,199 Total &nbsp; 6,781,841 &nbsp; 7,054,783 &nbsp; Collateral for credit card operations &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023, the Group had US$309 (US$305 on December 31, 2022) of security deposits granted in favor of Mastercard. These security deposits are measured at fair value through profit (loss) and are held as collateral for the amounts payable to the network and can be replaced by other security deposits with similar characteristics. The average remuneration rate of those security deposits was 0.36% per month in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 (0.31% on December 31, 2022). &nbsp; &nbsp; 22. FINANCIAL LIABILITIES AT AMORTIZED COST &#8211; BORROWINGS AND FINANCING &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Borrowings and financing &nbsp; 651,181 &nbsp; 585,568 Total &nbsp; 651,181 &nbsp; 585,568 &nbsp; a) Borrowings and financings &nbsp; Borrowings and financings maturities are as follows: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 3 months &nbsp; 3 to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Borrowings and financings &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Term loan credit facility (i) &nbsp; 79 &nbsp; 36,134 &nbsp; 90,614 &nbsp; 126,827 Syndicated loan (ii) &nbsp; 115 &nbsp; 626 &nbsp; 523,613 &nbsp; 524,354 Total borrowings and financings &nbsp; 194 &nbsp; 36,760 &nbsp; 614,227 &nbsp; 651,181 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Up to 3 months &nbsp; 3 to 12 months &nbsp; Over 12 months &nbsp; Total Borrowings and financings &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Term loan credit facility (i) &nbsp; 3,100 &nbsp; 32,632 &nbsp; 82,462 &nbsp; 118,194 Syndicated loan (ii) &nbsp; 103 &nbsp; 2,494 &nbsp; 464,777 &nbsp; 467,374 Total borrowings and financings &nbsp; 3,203 &nbsp; 35,126 &nbsp; 547,239 &nbsp; 585,568 &nbsp; (i) Corresponds to two term loan credit facilities obtained by subsidiary Nu Servicios and reassigned to Nu Financiera, in Mexican pesos. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 50 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; (ii) Corresponds to two syndicated credit facilities. The first, in which Nu&#8217;s subsidiaries in Colombia and Mexico are the borrowers and the Company is acting as guarantor, the total amount of the credit facility is US$650,000, out of which US$ 625,000 is allocated to Nu Mexico and US$ 25,000 to Nu Colombia. The second, in which Nu Colombia SA has been granted a 3-year facility, the total amount corresponds to US$150,000 from IFC (International Finance Corporation), guaranteed by the Company. &nbsp; The terms and conditions of the loans outstanding as of March 31, 2023, are as follows: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 Borrowings and financing &nbsp; Country &nbsp; Currency &nbsp; Interest rate &nbsp; Maturity &nbsp; Principal amount &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Term loan credit facility &nbsp; Mexico &nbsp; MXN &nbsp; TIIE 182 + 1.0% up to 1.45% &nbsp; July 2023 up to November 2024 &nbsp; 110,000 Syndicated loan &nbsp; Mexico &nbsp; MXN &nbsp; TIIE 91 + 1.00% &nbsp; April 2025 &nbsp; 435,000 Syndicated loan &nbsp; Colombia &nbsp; COP &nbsp; IBR (1) + 1.0% up to 3.59% &nbsp; April 2025 up to January 2026 &nbsp; 45,000 (1) IBR: Bank Reference Indicator ( Indicador Bancario de Referencia ). &nbsp; Changes to borrowings and financings are as follows: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Term loan credit facility &nbsp; Syndicated loan &nbsp; Total &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at beginning of the period &nbsp; 118,194 &nbsp; 467,374 &nbsp; 585,568 New borrowings &nbsp; - &nbsp; 19,713 &nbsp; 19,713 Payments &#8211; principal &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; - Payments &#8211; interest &nbsp; (4,387) &nbsp; (14,416) &nbsp; (18,803) Interest accrued &nbsp; 3,527 &nbsp; 15,162 &nbsp; 18,689 Transaction costs &nbsp; - &nbsp; (737) &nbsp; (737) Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; 9,493 &nbsp; 37,258 &nbsp; 46,751 Balance at end of the period &nbsp; 126,827 &nbsp; 524,354 &nbsp; 651,181 &nbsp; &nbsp; 51 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Bills of exchange &nbsp; Term loan credit facility &nbsp; Bank borrowings &nbsp; Syndicated loan &nbsp; Total &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at beginning of the year &nbsp; 10,400 &nbsp; 136,843 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 147,243 Addition due to business combination &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 4,729 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 4,729 New borrowings &nbsp; - &nbsp; 121,142 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 460,000 &nbsp; 581,142 Payments &#8211; principal &nbsp; (9,447) &nbsp; (146,078) &nbsp; (4,458) &nbsp; - &nbsp; (159,983) Payments &#8211; interest &nbsp; (1,889) &nbsp; (8,301) &nbsp; (568) &nbsp; (19,998) &nbsp; (30,756) Interest accrued &nbsp; 42 &nbsp; 8,340 &nbsp; 158 &nbsp; 22,534 &nbsp; 31,074 Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; 894 &nbsp; 6,248 &nbsp; 139 &nbsp; 4,838 &nbsp; 12,119 Balance at end of the year &nbsp; - &nbsp; 118,194 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 467,374 &nbsp; 585,568 &nbsp; Covenants &nbsp; The restrictive clauses (covenants) associated with the Group's debt contracts establish the maintenance of minimum financial indicators resulting from its capital, funding and liquidity (cash) position, as well as profitability metrics and leverage ratios including, but not limited to, net debt to gross profit, in addition to non-financial indicators according to each contract. The Group was compliant with such restrictive clauses as of March 31, 2023, and December 31, 2022. &nbsp; Guarantees &nbsp; The Company is guarantor to the above-mentioned borrowings from Colombia and Mexico. The subsidiary Nu Pagamentos is also a guarantor to certain term loan credit facilities. &nbsp; &nbsp; 23. PROVISION FOR LAWSUITS AND ADMINISTRATIVE PROCEEDINGS &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Tax risks &nbsp; 16,423 &nbsp; 15,747 Civil risks &nbsp; 3,422 &nbsp; 2,096 Labor risks &nbsp; 143 &nbsp; 104 Total &nbsp; 19,988 &nbsp; 17,947 &nbsp; The Company and its subsidiaries are parties to lawsuits and administrative proceedings arising from time to time in the ordinary course of operations, involving tax, civil and labor matters. Such matters are being discussed at the administrative and judicial levels, which, when applicable, are supported by judicial deposits. The provisions for probable losses arising from these matters are estimated and periodically adjusted by management, supported by external legal advisors&#8217; opinion. There is significant uncertainty relating to the timing of any cash outflow, if any, for civil and labor risk. &nbsp; &nbsp; 52 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; a) Provision &nbsp; Regarding tax risks, a provision in the amount of US$16,423 as of March 31, 2023 (US$15,747 on December 31, 2022) mainly refers to a potential legal obligation related to the increase in the contribution of certain Brazilian taxes (PIS and COFINS). The Group has a judicial deposit in the amount related to this claim, as shown below in item c). In June 2019, Nu withdrew the lawsuit and is currently awaiting the release of the judicial deposits to the Brazilian Tax Authorities. &nbsp; Civil lawsuits are mainly related to credit card operations. Based on management&#8217;s assessment and inputs from Nu&#8217;s external legal advisors, the Group has provisioned US$3,422 (US$2,096 on December 31, 2022) considered sufficient to cover estimated losses from civil suits deemed probable. &nbsp; b) Changes &nbsp; Changes to provision for lawsuits and administrative proceedings are as follows: &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Tax &nbsp; Civil &nbsp; Labor &nbsp; Tax &nbsp; Civil &nbsp; Labor &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Balance at beginning of the period &nbsp; 15,747 &nbsp; 2,096 &nbsp; 104 &nbsp; 17,081 &nbsp; 980 &nbsp; 21 Additions &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,486 &nbsp; 61 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,942 &nbsp; 100 Payments / Reversals &nbsp; - &nbsp; (281) &nbsp; (27) &nbsp; (2,341) &nbsp; (857) &nbsp; (18) Effect of changes in exchange rates (OCI) &nbsp; 676 &nbsp; 121 &nbsp; 5 &nbsp; 1,007 &nbsp; 31 &nbsp; 1 Balance at end of the period &nbsp; 16,423 &nbsp; 3,422 &nbsp; 143 &nbsp; 15,747 &nbsp; 2,096 &nbsp; 104 &nbsp; c) Contingencies &nbsp; The Group is a party to civil and labor lawsuits, involving risks classified by management and the legal advisors as possible losses, totaling approximately US$11,424 and US$2,859, respectively (US$7,128 and US$1,814 on December 31, 2022). Based on management&#8217;s assessment and inputs from the Group&#8217;s external legal advisors, no provision was recognized for those lawsuits as of March 31, 2023, and December 31, 2022. &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023, the total amount of judicial deposits shown as &#8220;Other assets&#8221; (note 17) is US$19,780 (US$18,864 on December 31, 2022) and is substantially related to the tax proceedings. &nbsp; &nbsp; 24. Deferred income &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 Deferred revenue from rewards program &nbsp; 41,742 &nbsp; 34,546 Deferred annual fee from reward program &nbsp; 3,290 &nbsp; 3,283 Other deferred income &nbsp; 2,090 &nbsp; 3,859 Total &nbsp; 47,122 &nbsp; 41,688 &nbsp; 53 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deferred revenue from rewards programs is related to the Group's reward program for its credit card customers, called &quot;Rewards&quot;. The program consists of accumulating points according to the use of the credit card in the ratio of R$1.00 (one Brazilian real, equivalent to US$0.20 as of March 31, 2023 (US$0.19 as of December 31, 2022)) equal to 1 point and cashbacks. The points do not expire, and there is no limit on the number of Rewards an eligible card member can earn. Deferred annual fees from reward program comprise amounts related to the rewards fees which are paid annually by customers until they are earned. &nbsp; The redemption of the points occurs when the customers use them in various expense categories, such as air tickets, hotels, transportation services, and music. &nbsp; Nu uses financial models to estimate the redemption rates of rewards earned to date by current card members, and, therefore, the estimated financial value of the points, based on historical redemption trends, current enrollee redemption behavior, among others. The estimated financial value is recorded in the profit or loss when the performance obligation is satisfied, which is when the reward points are redeemed. &nbsp; &nbsp; 25. RELATED PARTIES &nbsp; In the ordinary course of business, the Group may have issued credit cards or loans to Nu&#8217;s executive directors, board members, key employees and close family members. Those transactions, as well as the deposits and other products, as investments, occur on similar terms as those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions to unrelated persons and do not involve more than the normal risk of collectability. &nbsp; As described in note 3, &quot;Basis of consolidation&quot;, all companies from the Group are consolidated in these unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements. Therefore, related party balances and transactions, and any unrealized income and expenses arising from inter-company transactions, are eliminated in the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements. &nbsp; In 2023, the exchange differences arising from intercompany loans between entities of the group with different functional currencies are shown as &#8220;Interest income and gains (losses) on financial instruments&#8221; in the statement of profit (loss). &nbsp; a) Transactions with other related parties &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Assets/ (Liabilities) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Others &nbsp; - &nbsp; 316 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Revenues (expenses) &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Others &nbsp; - &nbsp; (1,112) &nbsp; &nbsp; 54 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; As of March 31, 2023 the Company did not have any transaction with other related parties. On June 30, 2021, the Group entered into a service and naming rights agreement with Rodamoinho Produtora de Eventos Ltda., owned by a former member of the Company&#8217;s Board of Directors (&quot;Board&quot;). This director has not been a member of the Board since September, 2022, when the Company ceased recognizing Rodamoinho as a related party. In addition, the Group did not make payments for Reprograma, a philanthropic project managed by a family member of the Company&#8217;s controlling shareholder, in the three-month period ended March 31, 2023. &nbsp; &nbsp; 26. FAIR VALUE MEASUREMENT &nbsp; The main valuation techniques employed in internal models to measure the fair value of the financial instruments as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022 are set out below. The principal inputs into these models are derived from observable market data. The Group did not make any material changes to its valuation techniques and internal models in those periods. &nbsp; a) Fair value of financial instruments carried at amortized cost &nbsp; The following tables show the fair value of the financial instruments carried at amortized cost as of March 31, 2023, and December 31, 2022. The Group has not disclosed the fair values of financial instruments such as compulsory and other deposits at central banks, other financial assets at amortized cost, deposits in electronic money, RDB and borrowings and financing, because their carrying amounts are a reasonable approximation of fair value. &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Carrying amount &nbsp; Fair value - Level 2 &nbsp; Fair value - Level 3 &nbsp; Carrying amount &nbsp; Fair value - Level 2 &nbsp; Fair value - Level 3 Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Compulsory and other deposits at central banks &nbsp; 2,671,668 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 2,778,019 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Credit card receivables (i) &nbsp; 9,158,470 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 9,109,455 &nbsp; 8,233,123 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 8,204,077 Loans to customers (i) &nbsp; 2,021,508 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2,238,328 &nbsp; 1,676,276 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,920,518 Other receivables &nbsp; 1,076,681 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,078,339 &nbsp; 521,670 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 522,359 Other financial assets &nbsp; 102,592 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 478,283 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Total &nbsp; 15,030,919 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 12,426,122 &nbsp; 13,687,371 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 10,646,954 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Deposits in electronic money &nbsp; 1,236,940 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 1,534,582 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Bank receipt of deposits (RDB) &nbsp; 14,520,723 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 14,273,959 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Payables to network &nbsp; 6,871,826 &nbsp; 6,472,107 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 7,054,783 &nbsp; 6,399,704 &nbsp; - Borrowings and financing &nbsp; 651,181 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 585,568 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Total &nbsp; 23,280,670 &nbsp; 6,472,107 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 23,448,892 &nbsp; 6,399,704 &nbsp; - (i) It excludes the fair value adjustment from the hedge accounting. &nbsp; &nbsp; 55 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; The book value from credit card receivables and loans to customers includes the amounts that are the hedge items of the portfolio hedge, described in note 18. The credit risk components for both receivables are not part of the hedge strategy. &nbsp; Borrowings and financing fair value is equal to the book value given that any prepayment shall be equal to the total outstanding amount. The fair value of floating rate demand deposits are assumed to be equal to carrying amounts. &nbsp; The valuation approach to specific categories of financial instruments is described below. &nbsp; i) Fair value models and inputs &nbsp; Credit card: The fair values of credit card receivables and payables to network are calculated using the discounted cash flow method. Fair values are determined by discounting the contractual cash flows by the interest rate curve and a credit spread. For payables, cash flows are also discounted by the Group's own credit spread. For past due receivables, the Group used the recovery rate of late payments as an input that is not directly observable and was estimated using the Group's internal databases. Loans to customers: Fair value is estimated based on groups of clients with similar risk profiles, using valuation models. The fair value of a loan is determined by discounting the contractual cash flows by the risk-free interest rate curve and a credit spread. For past due receivables, the Group used the recovery rate of late payments as an input that is not directly observable and was estimated using the Group's internal databases. Other receivables: Fair value is calculated by discounting future cash flows by a risk free interest rate and a credit spread. &nbsp; b) Fair value of financial instruments measured at fair value &nbsp; The following table shows a summary of the fair values, as of March 31, 2023, and December 31, 2022, of the financial assets and liabilities indicated below, classified on the basis of the various measurement methods used by the Group to determine their fair value: &nbsp; &nbsp; 56 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; Published price quotations in active markets (Level 1) &nbsp; Internal Models (Level 2) &nbsp; Internal Models (Level 3) &nbsp; Total Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Government bonds &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 6,367,862 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 6,367,862 United States &nbsp; 193,427 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 193,427 Mexico &nbsp; 1,376 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,376 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Corporate bonds and other instruments &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Certificate of bank deposits (CDB) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 3,135 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 3,135 Investment funds &nbsp; - &nbsp; 260,981 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 260,981 Time deposit &nbsp; - &nbsp; 246,153 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 246,153 Bill of credit (LC) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2 Real estate and agribusiness certificate of receivables (CRIs/CRAs) &nbsp; 6,297 &nbsp; 14,211 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 20,508 Real estate and agribusiness letter of credit (LCIs/LCAs) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 203 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 203 Corporate bonds and debentures &nbsp; 662,201 &nbsp; 232,120 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 894,321 Equity instrument &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 22,213 &nbsp; 22,213 Derivative financial instruments &nbsp; 263 &nbsp; 4,813 &nbsp; 9,610 &nbsp; 14,686 Collateral for credit card operations &nbsp; - &nbsp; 309 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 309 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Derivative financial instruments &nbsp; 1,941 &nbsp; 8,403 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 10,344 Instruments eligible as capital &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2,932 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 2,932 Repurchase agreements &nbsp; - &nbsp; 144,159 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 144,159 &nbsp; &nbsp; 57 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; &nbsp; Published price quotations in active markets (Level 1) &nbsp; Internal Models (Level 2) &nbsp; Internal Models (Level 3) &nbsp; Total Assets &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Government bonds &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Brazil &nbsp; 8,222,278 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 8,222,278 United States &nbsp; 171,184 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 171,184 Mexico &nbsp; 1,382 &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,382 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Corporate bonds and other instruments &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Certificate of bank deposits (CDB) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 3,712 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 3,712 Investment funds &nbsp; - &nbsp; 302,779 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 302,779 Time deposit &nbsp; - &nbsp; 446,436 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 446,436 Bill of credit (LC) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 138 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 138 Real estate and agribusiness certificate of receivables (CRIs/CRAs) &nbsp; 2 &nbsp; 32,173 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 32,175 Real estate and agribusiness letter of credit (LCIs/LCAs) &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,197 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 1,197 Corporate bonds and debentures &nbsp; 676,953 &nbsp; 158,675 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 835,628 Equity instrument &nbsp; - &nbsp; - &nbsp; 22,082 &nbsp; 22,082 Derivative financial instruments &nbsp; 2,154 &nbsp; 11,423 &nbsp; 27,908 &nbsp; 41,485 Collateral for credit card operations &nbsp; - &nbsp; 305 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 305 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Liabilities &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Derivative financial instruments &nbsp; 384 &nbsp; 9,041 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 9,425 Instruments eligible as capital &nbsp; - &nbsp; 11,507 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 11,507 Repurchase agreements &nbsp; - &nbsp; 197,242 &nbsp; - &nbsp; 197,242 &nbsp; i) Fair value models and inputs Securities: The securities with high liquidity and quoted prices in the active market are classified as level 1. Therefore, all the government bonds and some corporate bonds are included in level 1 as they are traded in active markets. Brazilian securities values are the published prices by the 'Associa&ccedil;&atilde;o Brasileira das Entidades dos Mercados Financeiro e de Capitais' (&#8220;Anbima&#8221;). For US, Mexico and Colombia bonds, fair values are the published prices by Bloomberg. Other corporate bonds and investment fund shares, whose valuation is based on observable data, such as interest rates and interest rate curves are classified as level 2. Derivatives : Derivatives traded on stock exchanges are classified as level 1 of the hierarchy. Derivatives traded on the Brazilian stock exchange are fairly valued using B3 quotations. Interest rate OTC Swaps are valued by discounting future expected cash flows to present values using interest rate curves and are classified as level 2. The embedded derivative conversion feature from the senior preferred share was calculated based on methodologies for the share price described in note 10. The options related to the warrant from Creditas Partnership are fair valued using a Black-Scholes model and are classified as level 3. &nbsp; 58 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Equity instrument: For the fair value of the equity instrument, the Group used contractual conditions as inputs that are not directly observable, and therefore it is classified as level 3. Instruments eligible as capital: If the instrument has an active market, prices quoted in this market are used. Otherwise, valuation techniques are used, such as discounted cash flows, where cash flows are discounted by a risk-free rate and a credit spread. Instruments eligible as capital were designated at fair value through profit (loss) in the initial recognition (fair value option). The fair value is the transaction value itself given that it is a short-term one day agreement. Repurchase agreements: The fair value is the transaction value itself given that repurchase agreement is a collateralized short-term one day agreement. &nbsp; c) Transfers between levels of the fair value hierarchy &nbsp; For the three-month period ended March 31, 2023 and year ended December 31, 2022, there were no transfers of financial instruments between levels 1 and 2 or between levels 2 and 3. &nbsp; &nbsp; 27. INCOME TAX &nbsp; Current and deferred taxes are determined for all transactions that have been recognized in the unaudited interim condensed consolidated financial statements using the provisions of the current tax laws. The current income tax expense or benefit represents the estimated taxes to be paid or refunded, respectively, for the current period. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on differences between the financial reporting and tax basis of assets and liabilities. They are measured using the tax rates and laws that will be in effect when the temporary tax differences are expected to reverse. &nbsp; a) Income tax reconciliation &nbsp; The tax on the Group's pre-tax profit differs from the theoretical amount that would arise using the weighted average tax rate applicable to profits of the consolidated entities. Thus, the following is a reconciliation of income tax expense to profit (loss) for the period, calculated by applying the combined Brazilian income tax rate o f 40% for the three-month periods ended March 31 , 2023 and 2022: &nbsp; &nbsp; 59 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Three-month period ended &nbsp; &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; 03/31/2022 Profit (loss) before income tax &nbsp; 243,629 &nbsp; (67,651) Tax rate (i) &nbsp; 40% &nbsp; 40% Income tax benefit &nbsp; (97,452) &nbsp; 27,060 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Permanent additions/exclusions &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Share-based payments &nbsp; (6,517) &nbsp; (10,907) Operational losses and others &nbsp; (3,812) &nbsp; (2,201) Foreign exchange variation on investments abroad &nbsp; 1,777 &nbsp; 3,974 Effect of different tax rates - subsidiaries and parent company &nbsp; 3,382 &nbsp; 4,972 Other non-deductible expenses &nbsp; 744 &nbsp; (251) Income tax &nbsp; (101,878) &nbsp; 22,647 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Current tax expense &nbsp; (205,864) &nbsp; (99,052) Deferred tax benefit &nbsp; 103,986 &nbsp; 121,699 Income tax in the statement of profit or loss &nbsp; (101,878) &nbsp; 22,647 Deferred tax recognized in OCI &nbsp; 3,211 &nbsp; 2,070 Income tax &nbsp; (98,667) &nbsp; 24,717 Effective tax rate &nbsp; 41.8% &nbsp; -33.5% &nbsp; (i) The tax rate used was the one applicable to the financial Brazilian subsidiaries, which represent the most significant portion of the operations of the Group. The tax rate used is not materially different from the average effective tax rate considering all jurisdictions where the Group has operations. The effect of other tax rates is shown in the table above as &#8220;effect of different tax rates &#8211; subsidiaries and parent company&#8221;. &nbsp; b) Deferred income taxes &nbsp; The following tables present significant components of the Group&#8217;s deferred tax assets and liabilities as of March 31, 2023 and December 31, 2022, and the changes for the periods then ended. The accounting records of deferred tax assets on income tax losses and/or social contribution loss carryforwards, as well as those arising from timing differences, are based on technical feasibility studies which consider the expected generation of future taxable income, considering the history of profitability for each subsidiary individually. The Group has no time limit for use of the deferred tax assets, but the use of the deferred tax asset related to tax loss and negative basis of social contribution is limited to 30% of taxable profit per year for the Brazilian entities. &nbsp; &nbsp; 60 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Nu Holdings Ltd. Unaudited Interim Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements as of March 31, 2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; Reflected in the statement of profit or loss &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; 12/31/2022 &nbsp; Constitution &nbsp; Realization &nbsp; Foreign exchange &nbsp; Reflected in OCI &nbsp; 03/31/2023 &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp; &nbsp;
